trans-unit.source: Build a service using an existing SQL database with the Mobile Services .NET backend | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Build a service using an existing SQL database with the Mobile Services .NET backend | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use an existing cloud or on-premises SQL database with your .NET based mobile service
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use an existing cloud or on-premises SQL database with your .NET based mobile service

trans-unit.source: Build a service using an existing SQL database with the Mobile Services .NET backend
trans-unit.target: Build a service using an existing SQL database with the Mobile Services .NET backend

trans-unit.source: The Mobile Services .NET backend makes it easy to take advantage of existing assets in building a mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The Mobile Services .NET backend makes it easy to take advantage of existing assets in building a mobile service.

trans-unit.source: One particularly interesting scenario is using an existing SQL database (either on-premises or in the cloud), that may already be used by other applications, to make existing data available to mobile clients.
trans-unit.target: One particularly interesting scenario is using an existing SQL database (either on-premises or in the cloud), that may already be used by other applications, to make existing data available to mobile clients.

trans-unit.source: In this case it's a requirement that database model (or *schema*) remain unchanged, in order for existing solutions to continue working.
trans-unit.target: In this case it's a requirement that database model (or *schema*) remain unchanged, in order for existing solutions to continue working.

trans-unit.source: Exploring the existing database model
trans-unit.target: Exploring the existing database model

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial we will use the database that was created with your mobile service, but we will not use the default model that is created.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial we will use the database that was created with your mobile service, but we will not use the default model that is created.

trans-unit.source: Instead, we will manually create an arbitrary model that will represent an existing application that you may have.
trans-unit.target: Instead, we will manually create an arbitrary model that will represent an existing application that you may have.

trans-unit.source: For full details about how to connect to an on-premises database instead, check out [Connect to an on-premises SQL Server from an Azure mobile service using Hybrid Connections](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-hybrid-connections-get-started.md).
trans-unit.target: For full details about how to connect to an on-premises database instead, check out [Connect to an on-premises SQL Server from an Azure mobile service using Hybrid Connections](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-hybrid-connections-get-started.md).

trans-unit.source: Start by creating a Mobile Services server project in **Visual Studio 2013 Update 2** or by using the quickstart project that you can download on the Mobile Services tab for your service in the [Azure classic portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com).
trans-unit.target: Start by creating a Mobile Services server project in **Visual Studio 2013 Update 2** or by using the quickstart project that you can download on the Mobile Services tab for your service in the [Azure classic portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com).

trans-unit.source: For the purposes of this tutorial, we will assume your server project name is **ShoppingService**.
trans-unit.target: For the purposes of this tutorial, we will assume your server project name is **ShoppingService**.

trans-unit.source: Create a **Customer.cs** file inside the **Models** folder and use the following implementation.
trans-unit.target: Create a **Customer.cs** file inside the **Models** folder and use the following implementation.

trans-unit.source: You will need to add an assembly reference to **System.ComponentModel.DataAnnotations** to your project.
trans-unit.target: You will need to add an assembly reference to **System.ComponentModel.DataAnnotations** to your project.

trans-unit.source: Create an **Order.cs** file inside the **Models** folder and use the following implementation:
trans-unit.target: Create an **Order.cs** file inside the **Models** folder and use the following implementation:

trans-unit.source: You will note that these two classes have a *relationship*: every **Order** is associated with a single **Customer** and a **Customer** can be associated with multiple **Orders**.
trans-unit.target: You will note that these two classes have a *relationship*: every **Order** is associated with a single **Customer** and a **Customer** can be associated with multiple **Orders**.

trans-unit.source: Having relationships is common in existing data models.
trans-unit.target: Having relationships is common in existing data models.

trans-unit.source: Create an **ExistingContext.cs** file inside the **Models** folder and implement it as so:
trans-unit.target: Create an **ExistingContext.cs** file inside the **Models** folder and implement it as so:

trans-unit.source: The structure above approximates an existing Entity Framework model that you may already be using for an existing application.
trans-unit.target: The structure above approximates an existing Entity Framework model that you may already be using for an existing application.

trans-unit.source: Please note that the model is not aware of Mobile Services in any way at this stage.
trans-unit.target: Please note that the model is not aware of Mobile Services in any way at this stage.

trans-unit.source: Creating data transfer objects (DTOs) for your mobile service
trans-unit.target: Creating data transfer objects (DTOs) for your mobile service

trans-unit.source: The data model you would like to use with your mobile service may be arbitrarily complex; it could contain hundreds of entities with a variety of relationships between them.
trans-unit.target: The data model you would like to use with your mobile service may be arbitrarily complex; it could contain hundreds of entities with a variety of relationships between them.

trans-unit.source: When building a mobile app, it is usually desirable to simplify the data model and eliminate relationships (or handle them manually) in order to minimize the payload being sent back and forth between the app and the service.
trans-unit.target: When building a mobile app, it is usually desirable to simplify the data model and eliminate relationships (or handle them manually) in order to minimize the payload being sent back and forth between the app and the service.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we will create a set of simplified objects (known as "data transfer objects" or "DTOs"), that are mapped to the data you have in your database, yet contain only the minimal set of properties needed by your mobile app.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we will create a set of simplified objects (known as "data transfer objects" or "DTOs"), that are mapped to the data you have in your database, yet contain only the minimal set of properties needed by your mobile app.

trans-unit.source: Create the **MobileCustomer.cs** file in the **DataObjects** folder of your service project and use the following implementation:
trans-unit.target: Create the **MobileCustomer.cs** file in the **DataObjects** folder of your service project and use the following implementation:

trans-unit.source: Note that this class is similar to the **Customer** class in the model, except the relationship property to **Order** is removed.
trans-unit.target: Note that this class is similar to the **Customer** class in the model, except the relationship property to **Order** is removed.

trans-unit.source: For an object to work correctly with Mobile Services offline sync, it needs a set of *system properties* for optimistic concurrency, so you will notice that the DTO inherits from [**EntityData**](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.windowsazure.mobile.service.entitydata.aspx), which contains those properties.
trans-unit.target: For an object to work correctly with Mobile Services offline sync, it needs a set of *system properties* for optimistic concurrency, so you will notice that the DTO inherits from [**EntityData**](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.windowsazure.mobile.service.entitydata.aspx), which contains those properties.

trans-unit.source: The int-based **CustomerId** property from the original model is replaced by the string-based **Id** property from **EntityData**, which will be the **Id** that Mobile Services will use.
trans-unit.target: The int-based **CustomerId** property from the original model is replaced by the string-based **Id** property from **EntityData**, which will be the **Id** that Mobile Services will use.

trans-unit.source: Create the **MobileOrder.cs** file in the **DataObjects** folder of your service project.
trans-unit.target: Create the **MobileOrder.cs** file in the **DataObjects** folder of your service project.

trans-unit.source: The **Customer** relationship property has been replaced with the **Customer** name and a **MobileCustomerId** property that can be used to manually model the relationship on the client.
trans-unit.target: The **Customer** relationship property has been replaced with the **Customer** name and a **MobileCustomerId** property that can be used to manually model the relationship on the client.

trans-unit.source: For now you can ignore the **CustomerId** property, it is only used later on.
trans-unit.target: For now you can ignore the **CustomerId** property, it is only used later on.

trans-unit.source: You might notice that with the addition of the system properties on the **EntityData** base class, our DTOs now have more properties than the model types.
trans-unit.target: You might notice that with the addition of the system properties on the **EntityData** base class, our DTOs now have more properties than the model types.

trans-unit.source: Clearly we need a place to store these properties, so we will add a few extra columns to the original database.
trans-unit.target: Clearly we need a place to store these properties, so we will add a few extra columns to the original database.

trans-unit.source: While this does change the database, it will not break existing applications since the changes are purely additive (adding new columns to the schema).
trans-unit.target: While this does change the database, it will not break existing applications since the changes are purely additive (adding new columns to the schema).

trans-unit.source: To do that, add the following statements to the top of **Customer.cs** and **Order.cs**:
trans-unit.target: To do that, add the following statements to the top of **Customer.cs** and **Order.cs**:

trans-unit.source: Next, add these extra properties to each of the classes:
trans-unit.target: Next, add these extra properties to each of the classes:

trans-unit.source: The system properties just added have some built-in behaviors (for example automatic update of created/updated at) that happen transparently with database operations.
trans-unit.target: The system properties just added have some built-in behaviors (for example automatic update of created/updated at) that happen transparently with database operations.

trans-unit.source: To enable these behaviors, we need to make a change to **ExistingContext.cs**.
trans-unit.target: To enable these behaviors, we need to make a change to **ExistingContext.cs**.

trans-unit.source: At the top of the file, add the following:
trans-unit.target: At the top of the file, add the following:

trans-unit.source: In the body of **ExistingContext**, override [**OnModelCreating**](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.data.entity.dbcontext.onmodelcreating.aspx):
trans-unit.target: In the body of **ExistingContext**, override [**OnModelCreating**](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.data.entity.dbcontext.onmodelcreating.aspx):

trans-unit.source: Let's populate the database with some example data.
trans-unit.target: Let's populate the database with some example data.

trans-unit.source: Open the file **WebApiConfig.cs**.
trans-unit.target: Open the file **WebApiConfig.cs**.

trans-unit.source: Create a new [**IDatabaseInitializer**](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/gg696323.aspx) and configure it in the **Register** method as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Create a new [**IDatabaseInitializer**](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/gg696323.aspx) and configure it in the **Register** method as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Establishing a mapping between DTOs and model
trans-unit.target: Establishing a mapping between DTOs and model

trans-unit.source: We now have the model types **Customer** and **Order** and the DTOs **MobileCustomer** and **MobileOrder**, but we need to instruct the backend to automatically transform between the two.
trans-unit.target: We now have the model types **Customer** and **Order** and the DTOs **MobileCustomer** and **MobileOrder**, but we need to instruct the backend to automatically transform between the two.

trans-unit.source: Here Mobile Services relies on [**AutoMapper**](http://automapper.org/), an object relational mapper, which is already referenced in the project.
trans-unit.target: Here Mobile Services relies on [**AutoMapper**](http://automapper.org/), an object relational mapper, which is already referenced in the project.

trans-unit.source: Add the following to the top of **WebApiConfig.cs**:
trans-unit.target: Add the following to the top of **WebApiConfig.cs**:

trans-unit.source: To define the mapping, add the following to the **Register** method of the **WebApiConfig** class.
trans-unit.target: To define the mapping, add the following to the **Register** method of the **WebApiConfig** class.

trans-unit.source: AutoMapper will now map the objects to one another.
trans-unit.target: AutoMapper will now map the objects to one another.

trans-unit.source: All properties with corresponding names will be matched, for example **MobileOrder.CustomerId** will get automatically mapped to **Order.CustomerId**.
trans-unit.target: All properties with corresponding names will be matched, for example **MobileOrder.CustomerId** will get automatically mapped to **Order.CustomerId**.

trans-unit.source: Custom mappings can be configured as shown above, where we map the **MobileCustomerName** property to the **Name** property of the **Customer** relationship property.
trans-unit.target: Custom mappings can be configured as shown above, where we map the **MobileCustomerName** property to the **Name** property of the **Customer** relationship property.

trans-unit.source: Implementing domain-specific logic
trans-unit.target: Implementing domain-specific logic

trans-unit.source: The next step is to implement a [**MappedEntityDomainManager**](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn643300.aspx), which serves as an abstraction layer between our mapped data store and the controller which will serve HTTP traffic from our clients.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to implement a [**MappedEntityDomainManager**](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn643300.aspx), which serves as an abstraction layer between our mapped data store and the controller which will serve HTTP traffic from our clients.

trans-unit.source: We will be able to write our controller in the next section purely in terms of the DTOs and the **MappedEntityDomainManager** we add here will handle the communication with the original data store, while also giving us a place to implement any logic specific to it.
trans-unit.target: We will be able to write our controller in the next section purely in terms of the DTOs and the **MappedEntityDomainManager** we add here will handle the communication with the original data store, while also giving us a place to implement any logic specific to it.

trans-unit.source: Add a **MobileCustomerDomainManager.cs** to the **Models** folder of your project.
trans-unit.target: Add a **MobileCustomerDomainManager.cs** to the **Models** folder of your project.

trans-unit.source: Paste in the following implementation:
trans-unit.target: Paste in the following implementation:

trans-unit.source: An important part of this class is the **GetKey** method where we indicate how to locate the ID property of the object in the original data model.
trans-unit.target: An important part of this class is the **GetKey** method where we indicate how to locate the ID property of the object in the original data model.

trans-unit.source: Add a **MobileOrderDomainManager.cs** to the **Models** folder of your project:
trans-unit.target: Add a **MobileOrderDomainManager.cs** to the **Models** folder of your project:

trans-unit.source: In this case the **InsertAsync** and **UpdateAsync** methods are interesting; that's where we enforce the relationship that each **Order** must have a valid associated **Customer**.
trans-unit.target: In this case the **InsertAsync** and **UpdateAsync** methods are interesting; that's where we enforce the relationship that each **Order** must have a valid associated **Customer**.

trans-unit.source: In **InsertAsync** you'll notice that we populate the **MobileOrder.CustomerId** property, which maps to the **Order.CustomerId** property.
trans-unit.target: In **InsertAsync** you'll notice that we populate the **MobileOrder.CustomerId** property, which maps to the **Order.CustomerId** property.

trans-unit.source: We get that value based by looking up the **Customer** with the matching **MobileOrder.MobileCustomerId**.
trans-unit.target: We get that value based by looking up the **Customer** with the matching **MobileOrder.MobileCustomerId**.

trans-unit.source: This is because by default the client is only aware of the Mobile Services ID (**MobileOrder.MobileCustomerId**) of the **Customer**, which is different than its actual primary key needed to set the foreign key (**MobileOrder.CustomerId**) from **Order** to **Customer**.
trans-unit.target: This is because by default the client is only aware of the Mobile Services ID (**MobileOrder.MobileCustomerId**) of the **Customer**, which is different than its actual primary key needed to set the foreign key (**MobileOrder.CustomerId**) from **Order** to **Customer**.

trans-unit.source: This is only used internally within the service to facilitate the insert operation.
trans-unit.target: This is only used internally within the service to facilitate the insert operation.

trans-unit.source: We are now ready to create controllers to expose our DTOs to our clients.
trans-unit.target: We are now ready to create controllers to expose our DTOs to our clients.

trans-unit.source: Implementing a TableController using DTOs
trans-unit.target: Implementing a TableController using DTOs

trans-unit.source: In the **Controllers** folder, add the file **MobileCustomerController.cs**:
trans-unit.target: In the **Controllers** folder, add the file **MobileCustomerController.cs**:

trans-unit.source: You will note the use of the AuthorizeLevel attribute to restrict public access to the Insert/Update/Delete operations on the controller.
trans-unit.target: You will note the use of the AuthorizeLevel attribute to restrict public access to the Insert/Update/Delete operations on the controller.

trans-unit.source: For the purposes of this scenario, the list of Customers will be read-only, but we will allow the creation of new Orders and associating them with existing customers.
trans-unit.target: For the purposes of this scenario, the list of Customers will be read-only, but we will allow the creation of new Orders and associating them with existing customers.

trans-unit.source: In the **Controllers** folder, add the file **MobileOrderController.cs**:
trans-unit.target: In the **Controllers** folder, add the file **MobileOrderController.cs**:

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to run your service.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to run your service.

trans-unit.source: Press **F5** and use the test client built into the help page to modify the data.
trans-unit.target: Press **F5** and use the test client built into the help page to modify the data.

trans-unit.source: Please note that both controller implementations make exclusive use of the DTOs **MobileCustomer** and **MobileOrder** and are agnostic of the underlying model.
trans-unit.target: Please note that both controller implementations make exclusive use of the DTOs **MobileCustomer** and **MobileOrder** and are agnostic of the underlying model.

trans-unit.source: These DTOs are readily serialized to JSON and can be used to exchange data with the Mobile Services client SDK on all platforms.
trans-unit.target: These DTOs are readily serialized to JSON and can be used to exchange data with the Mobile Services client SDK on all platforms.

trans-unit.source: For example, building a Windows Store app, the corresponding client-side type would look as shown below.
trans-unit.target: For example, building a Windows Store app, the corresponding client-side type would look as shown below.

trans-unit.source: The type would be analogous on other client platforms.
trans-unit.target: The type would be analogous on other client platforms.

trans-unit.source: As a next step, you can now build out the client app to access the service.
trans-unit.target: As a next step, you can now build out the client app to access the service.
